Award.AwardTitle: Nanoscale Metal Network Enhanced Phase Change Materials

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Renewable energy sources such as solar energy, geothermal energy, and wind energy require effective and efficient thermal storage systems. Latent heat storage is an approach which can be accomplished using certain kinds of materials, including those known as Phase Change Materials, which have the ability to store energy at near constant temperature. However, most Phase Change Materials have unacceptably low thermal conductivities, and therefore their applications for high power, transient, and large-scale renewable energy systems are significantly limited. This award supports the study of a manufacturing process to synthesize and embed a nanoscale metallic network into phase change materials, taking advantage of the high thermal conductivity of the metallic network, to significantly improve thermal performance of Phase Change Material-based energy storage systems. This new type of Phase Change Materials would impact the renewable energy storage industry and diverse applications such as flexible electronics, electronic cooling, and smart textiles. The knowledge acquired from this project will also contribute to other industries such as medical, automobile, food processing and semiconductor packaging. The integration of fundamental research together with the educational efforts will advance engineering education and promote this new and exciting field of science at the high school senior and college freshmen levels.

The objective of this research is to synthesize and study interrelationship among structures, processing and thermal properties of a novel phase change material embedded with a soldered metallic nanowire network. The major issues in nanoparticle-dispersed phase change materials include the settlement during melting-solidification cycling, and high interfacial thermal resistance of particles. The research is focused on fundamental issues in exploiting the new phase change material, such as soldering of nanowire-to-nanowire, nanowire-to-sidewall surface, and interactions between magnetic field and nanowires in phase change material fluids. A combined approach involving both modeling and theoretical analysis, and well-designed sets of experiments will be adopted to understand the relationships between network structure, processing parameters such as magnetic field strength, nanowire loading, spacing and size of magnetic pads, soldering temperature, and the resulting thermal properties of the new phase change material.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ever-increasing energy demand, accelerated race to energy independency, and concern over environmental impact has significantly accelerated the development of renewable energy sources such as solar energy, geothermal energy, and wind energy. Most renewable energy sources are intermittent in nature and require effective and efficient thermal storage systems. Latent heat storage is a particularly attractive technique due to its high capacity and its ability to store energy at near constant temperature corresponding to the phase transition temperature of the phase change materials (PCMs) such as paraffin. However, most PCMs have unacceptably low thermal conductivities and as a result, the current PCMs without thermal conductivity enhancement have very limited applications for high power, transient, and large-scale renewable energy systems. This project aims to synthesize a novel phase change material embedded with a soldered metallic nanowire network (nanoPCM) by taking advantage of the high thermal conductivity of metal matrix, to significantly improve thermal performance of PCM based energy storage systems. Another goal of the project is to seek an in-depth understanding of thermal transport mechanisms and interrelationships between structures, processing and thermal properties of nanoPCM.

In this project, both numerical and experimental methods were successfully applied to discover the phenomenon of alignment of nickel (Ni) nanowires under different magnetic fields which leads to the formation of nanowire columns in paraffin ? a commonly used phase change material. Furthermore, the nanowire column density can be controlled by fabricating microscale magnetic pads of different shapes to induce locally focused magnetic fields to guide the nanowires into desired columns along the fields.  The numerical simulation results show that the thermal conductivity of PCM can be significantly enhanced by the addition of these nanowire columns and the energy storage speed of nanoPCM is much higher than the conventional PCMs. The PIs also successfully fabricated multi-segmented Ni nanowires with Sn solder tips on both ends of the wires. Followed by a thermal soldering process, these nanowires formed a metal network in PCM with well-controlled structure and excellent mechanical stability. This research consisted of a systematic parametric study, including morphology characterization, combined with experimental and theoretical analysis to understand the fundamental mechanisms governing both the alignment of nanowires and joining processes of the metal network, as well as the resulting effect on thermal and mechanical behaviors.

This research introduced a new kind of phase change material that would impact the renewable energy storage industry and a number of diverse applications such as compact heat exchangers, electronic cooling, and smart textiles for thermal protection. Further research in this field contributes to the nanomanufacturing of composite materials that could potentially be used in industries such as medical, automobile, food processing and semiconductor packaging. An integrated research and education plan was adapted to improve the education of thermal-fluids and to promote nanotechnology at both undergraduate (especially freshmen) and graduate levels.
